text: hello and welcome to cupcake addictions
easy microwave modeling chocolate recipe
and tutorial where I'll be showing you
how to make some easy microwavable
modeling chocolate I've had so many
requests asking me to post a fondant
recipe and tutorial and I just haven't
come across a fondant recipe that I'm
happy to share that I actually like
working with so modeling chocolate is my
answer everything that I've done
throughout my tutorials that I've done
with fondant you can use modeling
chocolate for this handbag for example
is covered in modeling chocolate looks
fantastic it's easy to work with you can
make it at home and it tastes a lot
better equipment and ingredients that
I'll be using today I have a spoon I
have four tablespoons of glucose syrup
your equivalent in the US will be corn
syrup I have that in a bowl with one
tablespoon of just tap water and that's
been warmed up for about 30 seconds in
the microwave just to make it a lot more
fluid and a lot easier to mix through
the melted white chocolate white
chocolate I have 250 grams or nine
ounces now that needs to be melted as I
mentioned you can use a double boiler
but I like to pop mine in the microwave
for 30 second intervals stirring in
between until I'm happy that it's melted
it normally takes between a minute and a
half and two minutes I'm going to pop
that in the microwave now okay so I've
got my melted white chocolate well I've
been melting that I've also cleaned up
my workspace because we are going to
need quite a bit of room for this stage
melted white chocolate ended up taking
me four blasts of 30 seconds stirring
well in between make sure that you do
stir it well in between each 30 second
blast as chocolate melts best when it's
actually being agitated so it might not
look like it's melting but you don't
want to overcook your chocolate I've got
my glucose and water mixture as I
mentioned it's quite warm it's been
microwaved also for about 30 seconds so
I'm just going to pour that in and
taking the spoon I'm just going to stir
around so you can see there that clear
River on top of our glucose water
mixture now this is the part of your
modeling chocolate where it has a
tendency to go awry so what you want to
do is you want to make
sure that you don't overmix at this
stage you can see as I'm mixing there's
still little clear rivers of glucose
running through you want to mix until it
just comes together so until you just
get rid of those little clear rivers and
as soon as you can't see them anymore
stop mixing see I'm going around in some
nice big wide swirls rather than mixing
it really fast I just want to keep a bit
of control over the amount of mixing I'm
scraping right off to the corners so
that there is about perfect the way that
I tell is if you lift the spoon you can
see that chocolate is actually coming
off the bottom of the bowl there now at
this stage I'm going to take some cling
film or some plastic wrap forgive me I
should have actually mentioned to my
ingredients I'm going to take the cling
film and I'm just going to scoop that
modeling chocolate out onto the cling
film I'm going to fold the cling film
over I'm just going to spread that
modeling chocolate out this is just
going to help it set a little bit
quicker so it's not just a big clump
it's a little bit flatter and wider now
this I'm going to leave I would normally
leave this overnight or you can
refrigerate it for about three hours I
prefer to leave it overnight I just find
that it's a better set
I don't refrigerate it when I leave it
overnight I just leave it at room
temperature so when you're modeling
chocolate has had at about 12 hours or
so to set this is what you're left with
so you want to peel apart that plastic
wrap make sure not to leave any of it on
the modeling chocolate
just pull your modeling-chocolate out
now we're going to need the modeling
chocolate once again you don't want to
over need your modeling chocolate if it
starts to look greasy then you're over
needing it so if it starts a little
breezy don't worry just wrap it back up
and put it back in the fridge for an
hour or so until it comes back to a nice
firm consistency you can see there I'm
actually putting quite a bit of pressure
on this quite a bit of weight behind it
need it in between your hands if you
find that easier I'm not going to need
this for very long just a couple of
minutes just to smooth it out get a
lovely consistency now here you have
your finished modeling chocolate now for
this I now wrap it back up in cloud
plastic wrap and I like to leave it
overnight again before I actually add
any color it just helps it to settle
down and stops it from being so sticky
if you do want to color your modeling
chocolate use a color paste rather than
a liquid color if you do need to use a
liquid color only use it for really pale
colors the paste adds a lot less liquid
to the modeling chocolate and is less
likely to break up that consistency if
you find your modeling chocolate is
getting too sticky to work with pop it
back into the fridge for an hour or so
it just needs to set a little bit harder
you might find your hands are a little
bit warm as you're working with it now
modeling chocolate is absolutely
fantastic for like I said all kinds of
decorating figurine making and you'll
notice we use it a lot in upcoming
tutorials
